awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF: Collaborative Research: An Embodied Intelligent Cognitive Assistant to Enhance Cognitive Performance of Shift Workers
awd_abstract_narration:
The Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier (FW-HTF) is one of 10 new Big Ideas for Future Investment announced by NSF. The FW-HTF cross-directorate program aims to respond to the challenges and opportunities of the changing landscape of jobs and work by supporting convergent research. This award fulfills part of that aim.

This project develops a closed-loop embodied Intelligent Cognitive Assistant (e-ICA) to infer circadian rhythm, alertness, and stress levels and to provide personalized feedback to enhance users' cognitive ability and wellbeing in an unobtrusive and effortless manner. Approximately 20% of the labor force engages in shift work, which often leads to inadequate and poor sleep. Being out of synch with one's natural body clock, or circadian rhythm, can lead to many complications over time, including a higher likelihood for cardiovascular disease, cancer, obesity, and mental health problems. In addition, there can be serious deficits in cognitive performance, with productivity loss and more accidents in the workplace. This research program will design and develop a novel sensor-based e-ICA that can monitor shift workers' circadian rhythms, sleep patterns, and stress levels. The platform will be flexible so that it can be used to study broad populations in addition to shift workers. Given that 70 percent of the population suffers from circadian rhythm disruption, this technology has the potential to impact a wide range of workers and firms. In addition, the anonymized data and information about developed hardware and software will be shared in the community. The technology will impact the needs of a broad cross-section of stakeholders, but will be tested initially with medical residents and other health practitioners who typically work long shift that change every few weeks. Moreover, this project will also allow interdisciplinary cross fertilization between science, engineering, psychology, sleep and circadian biology, and psychiatry.

The investigators explore ways to provide biologically and physiologically attuned support in the areas of cognitive ability, performance, sleep, and well-being based on the inferred individual circadian rhythm and personalized embodied assistance by: a) passively and continuously gathering behavioral and physiological streams through wearable, mobile and remote devices from workers in an effortless manner; b) continuously inferring each person's individual circadian rhythm, alertness, and stress in daily life settings; and c) providing personalized multi-sensory feedback or actionable behavioral suggestions to modulate circadian rhythm, alertness and stress levels with the aim of  enhancing cognitive ability, performance and wellbeing. The investigators will test the efficacy, usability and acceptability of the system both in a series of laboratory studies and in an in-situ work environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our work has made significant strides in health monitoring and support for shift workers usingmobile technologies and machine learning. Below, we detail our key contributions and findings:


Measuring Circadian Rhythm and Wellbeing: We developed machine learning models to detect circadian phases using physiological and behavioral data from wearable sensors, based on the SNAPSHOT dataset. This dataset includes 1-3 months of daily measurements and DLMO assessments from 207 college students with irregular sleep cycles. Our two-step framework, which uses two-time scale features, proved more accurate than previous one-time scale models.

We built machine learning models to predict future momentary and long-term mood and stress using data from wearable devices and mobile phones. This included comparing various machine learning structures including automatic feature extraction, semi-supervised and self-supervised learning and personalization strategies. 


Developing Technologies for Regulating Alertness: We explored the effects of light brightness oscillation on alertness and productivity for shift workers and computer/mobile device users. Using heart rate to determine target oscillation frequencies, 36 participants participated in a cognitive task. Results showed that slow frequency stimulation caused a statistically significant delay in response time without affecting accuracy or sleepiness ratings. Frequency-dependent light stimulation also influenced HRV metrics, suggesting potential for unobtrusive user performance and physiological enhancement.


Personalized Sleep and Wellbeing Support: We deployed a personalized sleep and wellbeing support system for shift workers and collecting biobehavioral patterns using wearables and surveys. Our 4-week evaluation study with 61 participants showed a statistically significant increase in mean daily sleep duration and improved subjective sleep quality. We also developed a machine learning model to assist doctors in providing personalized advice to shift workers.


Burnout Analysis and Prediction: Our study integrates continuous biobehavioral data with psychosocial measures to predict burnout risk in health professionals.We collected data from nurses and doctors and built machine learning models to classify burnout risk to enhance early detection and mitigation.


Counterfactual Explanations for Burnout Prediction: Using the counterfactual framework, we generated interpretable explanations for burnout prediction models. Our experiments highlighted the importance of behavioral rhythm, sleep, and heart rate features in predicting burnout risk accurately.


Cross-Dataset Analysis of Burnout: We conducted a cross-dataset analysis of burnout using data from shift workers in multiple hospitals in multiple countries. Our findings revealed consistent contributors to burnout, such as heart rate metrics, and the importance of considering dataset characteristics for accurate prediction.


SleepNet for Sleep Prediction: SleepNet exploits social contagion in sleep behavior using graph networks and integrates it with physiological and phone data. Our system predicts next-day sleep duration, by incorporating an attention mechanism to improve performance. Extensive evaluation demonstrated SleepNet's robustness and the significance of social network topology in prediction accuracy.


Educational Activities: We extended this research to educational activities (research internships and workshops) for high school and undergraduate students and demonstrated real-world applications of wearable sensor data and future innovations in improving health and wellbeing.
